title: The "ideal" Duke experience
author: Valerie Tan
abstract: I was ashamed of not making full use of the plethora of resources available, and worried that my decision to sit out on many “core” experiences was diminishing the value and authenticity of my college experience—that it made me less of a Duke student.

title: Embracing the Mississippian parts of ourselves
author: Advikaa Anand
abstract: "Well, you don't seem like you're from Mississippi."

title: It’s time to umask the bus mask mandate
author: Sean Keating
abstract: Perhaps it is time to stop caring about optics, and start allowing your poor students to sip their Diet Dr. Peppers.

title: Response to Duke Climate Commitment
author: Elizabeth Albright
abstract: Duke University will be judged by current and future generations in the ways we decide to implement concrete, measurable, and forward thinking goals to ensure that our actions are as bold as our words.

title: Sexual assault: the harmful dichotomy between prevention and intervention
author: Billy Cao
abstract: It saddens me to see that, although new administrators have come to Duke with new sets of promises, they have reverted to the same words, defenses, and strategies against recurrent student grievances.

title: PSA Statement on Iran
author: Persian Students Association
abstract: Iranian women are not victims, they will emerge victors over a repressive regime.

title: How to Draw a Line
author: Ayesham Khan
abstract: I mean in the more emotional sense: how to draw. Like how to think. How to clear a mind. How to excavate it for memory.

title: I can’t menstruate. Here’s how the overturning of Roe v. Wade affects me.
author: Viktoria Wulff-Andersen
abstract: No one at Duke should be made to feel less like a woman because of their menstrual capabilities—not me, not a roommate, not a teacher, not a peer.

title: Unwritten rules for catching up with friends
author: Nathan Luzum
abstract: If the glint of the sun catches your dining partner’s eyes just right, it might just illuminate their intrinsic hopefulness and goodwill, revealing them as a bastion of radiance in a world of iniquity.

title: What's a criminal?
author: Sonia Green
abstract: The Duke community must make sure that the burden of reassuring others doesn’t fall on Black Duke.

title: On old friends
author: Laura Boyle
abstract: But, at college, we come to know that the value of a friend is found not in their proximity, but rather, in what happens in the gaps between.

title: Abolish fall break
author: Heidi Smith
abstract: Inherently, fall break isn't a horrible idea, but in practice it falls rather short.

title: Linguistics student accidentally rediscovers eldritch language
author: Monday Monday
abstract: I peeked into rooms that seemed, at least at a glance, impossible: a study space so large I couldn’t see the other end, a classroom with all the desks on the ceiling, and an affordable campus dining option.

title: A statement from GPSG’s Director of Environment and Sustainability regarding Duke’s Climate Commitment
author: Michelle Carter
abstract: I call for the administrators at Duke University to actively release their plans and updates for the implementation of climate and environmental concepts.

title: "People are not crimes."
author: Luke A. Powery
abstract: He recognizes that we human beings are not just broken; we are beautiful and gifted as well.

title: A statement on behalf of the Duke Climate Coalition regarding the September 29th Climate Commitment announcement
author: Duke Climate Coalition
abstract: Until Duke pledges to total [fossil fuel] divestment, the Climate Commitment will remain a statement of utter hypocrisy.

title: Editor's note: Explaining the retraction of an article from The Chronicle's website Friday afternoon
author: Milla Surjadi
abstract: On Wednesday, an article was published in the Recess section describing a writer’s experience at the Alec Benjamin concert at the Ritz in Raleigh.

title: Like lead-filled piñatas: the story of the Frangible Bullet Project, Duke’s largest military-funded research endeavor
author: Monika Narain
abstract: Sure, killing is an inevitable part of battle, but perhaps one could argue that, at least for the last year of the war, the American execution of every, well, enemy execution, can be inextricably traced to the Duke name.

title: Beyond the yellow wallpaper: A look into gendered medical gaslighting
author: Advikaa Anand
abstract: Their exhibitions of hysteria represented an attempt to seize masculine power, and it was the doctor’s job to return them to their natural feminine state---keeping them captive in their sickness.

title: Stop infantilizing us, Duke!
author: Miranda Straubel
abstract: Despite being an elite university, Duke sure knows how to treat its students like children.

title: Yesterday’s fear-mongering DukeAlert is indicative of the University’s failed attempts to address racial inequity
author: Tashia Ethridge
abstract: Yesterday's DukeAlert is something that should weigh heavily on the minds of the Duke community.

title: Humans stuck in Duke's institutional workshop
author: Abdel Shehata
abstract: The institutional system is designed to be as inefficient as possible in dealing with human concerns... In other words, the bureaucratic maze is not a fault of the system but the system itself.

title: You didn't understand the assignment
author: Linda Cao
abstract: But if you measure the value of school based on the number of facts you can whip out of your pocket, then I suppose you really didn’t understand the assignment.

title: Duke is on the wrong side of labor union history. Here’s its chance to get it right
author: Pilar Kelly
abstract: I urge the university to voluntarily recognize DGSU and thus signal a new age in labor relations. Duke has the power to symbolically depart from its part in the story of worker oppression– the beginning of which starts on the same plot of land that graduate students plant their table today.

title: Reflections on Latinx Heritage Month
author: Anthony Salgado
abstract: At an institution like Duke, finding people like you can be hard but you are making a generational path for others by doing so. Your future descendants are thanking you right now, so seize your opportunities and make them proud.

title: A tribute to Queen Elizabeth II
author: Sophie Ju
abstract: To many countries, she not only represented the companion of time and space, but also the spiritual bond—an embodiment of history, tradition and values.

title: Shana Tova! – Sincerely, Duke University
author: Dena Levin
abstract: 809 is the number of Jewish students who are forced to make the choice: go to class, or go to synagogue.

title: Pessimism is easy
author: Ooha Reddy
abstract: It felt selfish at points to put myself out there and advocate for an issue that felt like it only concerned me, but the people around me assured me that my own cause is still worth fighting for.

title: How Duke is failing sexual assault victims
author: Billy Cao
abstract: The Duke Today article is a quintessential example of the institution’s infantilization of students, antagonism towards advocates, dismissal of constructive criticism, and to be frank, perpetuation of patriarchal defenses.

title: ​​Why is GroupMe so terrible? The Windows XP of online communication
author: James Gao
abstract: Our campus – and all campuses – should have ways of connecting with others that are actually pleasant to use.

title: Who's expected to mourn the queen?
author: Sydney Brown
abstract: Who's allowed to mourn the queen? How are they allowed to do so?

title: Do nothing.
author: Spencer Chang
abstract: Do nothing.

title: All-time empathy is toxic
author: Chi Nghiem
abstract: Empathy is now not the pure act of altruism or cherishing but the norms that dictate one’s tie to a group or a person.

title: Duke doesn’t want me. Neither does my home.
author: Viktoria Wulff-Andersen
abstract: The thing about being constantly forced to confront your lack of a permanent residence is that you’re also forced to reconcile with the fact that you’re not as important to the trajectory of others as you might think. Life goes on regardless of if you’re there or not.

title: What's so special about peanuts?
author: Sonia Green
abstract: If Duke truly wants to be allergen-friendly, we should at least recognize more allergens than just peanuts and tree nuts.

title: Vote in North Carolina. Pretty please.
author: Chloe Decker
abstract: As one of only several North Carolina universities where the majority of the student body does not originate from within the state, Duke holds a unique position to contribute thousands of young, diverse voters to the electorate.

title: Straddling the fence
author: Valerie Tan
abstract: I quietly clung onto the selfish hope that everything could be frozen in time so that leaving could be as simple as hitting pause and returning, as effortless as picking up from where I left off.

title: It's okay to change your mind
author: Heidi Smith
abstract: I’ve come to the opinion that most things socially—obviously done in moderation and safely—can be a healthy break from the rigors and stresses of being a college student. This is almost embarrassingly banal, but it’s taken me a long time to get to this point.

title: Economics majors hold emergency council to address food point inflation
author: Monday Monday
abstract: “What if we made mobile orders into NFTs?”

title: Changing your mind
author: Luke A. Powery
abstract: Learning can be an expansion or deconstruction or construction or a deepening or an enlightening—and all of this is change.

title: This saga ends here
author: Ooha Reddy
abstract: Wednesday’s webinar droned on about the administration’s mission to create a “less fragmented community” and return students to their “home institution.” But DKU stopped being my home institution a while ago.

title: The “find your passion” narrative is a scam
author: Michelle Ling
abstract: Having a passion is not a requirement to be a valuable and interesting person, and we are not meant to be packaged and labeled into something that other people can decide the worth of.

title: North Carolina politics: past, present, and future
author: Miranda Straubel
abstract: I have faith that one day our state will be able to take decisive action on climate change, taking advantage of natural resources to eliminate fossil fuels. We will eventually have the nation’s best public schools and safest communities. One day we will become the progressive beacon we once were, uplifting every community.

title: Quarantine qualms: a reflection on contracting COVID-19 at the tail end of the pandemic
author: Advikaa Anand
abstract: I had contracted the virus when it no longer dominated media headlines, creating distance between its harrowing physical impacts and other people’s perceptions. Nor did Duke provide the same wealth of resources for those quarantined as it did earlier in the pandemic.

title: Stop disrespecting our bus drivers
author: Sonia Green
abstract: Not only does yelling show an utter lack of respect, it’s also pointless and promotes the stereotype of the “entitled Duke student.”

title: A Panda in a desert of bureaucracy
author: Abdel Shehata
abstract: It is easy to counteract the increase in dining prices through an increase in dining financial aid, subsidizing healthier food options on campus, and expanding the food point system to 9th Street restaurants. However, all those suggestions do is treat a symptom not the disease itself: the bureaucratic and non transparent nature of the Duke administration.

title: I'm okay with you being dead
author: Linda Cao
abstract: The idea of living with ambivalent feelings, a place without closure, is peculiarly uncomfortable.

title: SLGs or QuadEx? Why not both!
author: Pilar Kelly
abstract: QuadEx should be embraced as an addition, not a substitution, to community at Duke

title: As food rots, so does my heritage
author: Ayesham Khan
abstract: I am fearful of losing it all. Much of it is lost already, the intimacy of knowing the delivery boy, the closeness of picking out your fruit and meat, and the slowness of pickling your own carrots.

title: If you must be immoral, be honest about it
author: Dan Reznichenko
abstract: Nobody wants to admit that they’re making a choice that is some shade of gray.

title: The power of being alone
author: Sophie Ju
abstract: If there’s only one thing I hope to share with my peers in the Class of 2026, it’s that the foundation for us to connect with this new community is to first connect with ourselves.

title: Transcending sexual consent
author: Billy Cao
abstract: But in order for students to take consent to heart, they must first understand what makes wrongful sex wrong and undesirable sex undesirable, not the other way around.

title: It’s easy to be scared
author: Sydney Brown
abstract: What will your life be like if you allow yourself to choose one of them despite your fears? Where will you go? What will you miss out on if you don’t push through? A lot of life is what we make of it, so go do the thing that scares you the most.

title: How to lose a conversation
author: Chi Nghiem
abstract: In the search for a promptly sparking, effortlessly working romance, we objectify people, and that will in return objectify us.

title: A love letter to the lonely
author: Zoe Spicer
abstract: I wrote this letter to you in the hopes that it would make you feel a little less lonely.

title: Experiential orientation proposes an equity issue
author: Viktoria Wulff-Andersen
abstract: Understanding the far reach of accommodating and accounting for 1740 first-year students begged the question of where Duke would fall short.

title: On mortality and turning twenty
author: Laura Boyle
abstract: I want you to remember that to be alive is to die one day, and that you should never feel guilty for getting one more chance, one more morning, one more moment to experience, to grow, to regress, to be.

title: Here I go again
author: Valerie Tan
abstract: This time, no longer shackled by my overthinking tendencies, I will be brutally honest if I must and less afraid to infuse my writing with more personality.

title: A neophyte in the hospital
author: Nathan Luzum
abstract: The idea of being in the hospital so soon in your career seems great until you finish the first year and still feel woefully unprepared. But if life’s about anything, it’s about being woefully unprepared in as graceful a manner as possible.

title: The cost of eating at WU
author: Heidi Smith
abstract: The way Duke’s upperclassman food plan works majorly contributes to a culture of ignoring breakfast, replacing meals with coffee, pushing off eating until work is done, and choosing the cheap option over the more desirable one, behaviors that are not only encouraged but often lauded in that toxic “suffering more than thou” way of bragging.

title: The Empty Equity Center
author: Anthony Salgado
abstract: At the same time the Career Center was empty, Latinx students sat on the floor of their own space and had to grab chairs from across the Bryan Center.

title: Duke HRL introduces new TentEx program to address housing shortage
author: Monday Monday
abstract: This new housing option provides a variety of benefits for students, such as being closer to classrooms and libraries, making sure each resident gets plenty of fresh air, and promoting a better sleep schedule by getting rid of the ability to ignore the sun in the morning.

title: Learning humbly
author: Luke A. Powery
abstract: You have to be strong in order not to seek self-satisfaction, self-gratification or self-promotion.

title: SLG response to Duke admin
author: Duke SLGs
abstract: To diminish this source of community at all is disheartening; to diminish it sooner than we had expected is even more so.

title: An open letter to Dean Bill Boulding on decency
author: Jerry Chen
abstract: I am writing this letter to challenge your idea of a decency quotient and, more specifically, of recognizing DQ.

title: Elegy for Peaches, the placemaker
author: Jeff Nelson
abstract: Peaches the community cat, the placemaker—this is how I will remember her.

title: Tribute to Janet Hill
author: David Bowser
abstract: As the flags fly low on campus today (Thursday, August 18), please remember her and the great work she did helping to make Duke University what it is.

title: Concerned driver for Duke vans
author: Daniel Bradford
abstract: With only four to six van drivers, though, I anticipate wait times will be through the roof; some students and staff might end up taking the dangerous walk to their car or dorm/apartment late at night.

title: The personal damages of Proclamation 10043
author: Xu Weng
abstract: If I still can't get a visa this fall, I will give up the opportunity to study at Duke University.

title: An equitable Bryan Center
author: Anthony Salgado
abstract: Duke has once again failed diversity on campus. The Bryan Center must remain a student facing area, promoting equity and inclusivity.

title: Concerned alumni for the arts
author: Alumni for the Arts
abstract: We are asking you, President Price, and Provost Kornbluth, to conduct an urgent, independent review of Duke Arts and Duke Performances, including talking with past staff so their institutional knowledge can be carried forward.

title: Uvalde statement
author: Mi Gente Executive Council
abstract: These people will never take away our Latinx beauty, our resilience, or our bravery.

title: BSA Buffalo Shooting Statement
author: Duke Black Student Alliance
abstract: Similar sentiments have been expressed for decades. Now is not the time for realization but mobilization.

title: Jackie Looney, long vision, and equality
author: Andrew D. Jones, Jr.
abstract: Dean Jackie Looney retires this year. She was a beacon of opportunity for over 30 years for families who have struggled over generations.

title: Letters: Tributes to Nugget
author: NA
abstract: "I will miss Nugget, but I will live each day honoring her by remembering what joy an everyday interaction can bring into your life. She taught us how a positive presence can bring so much light into your day," Alex Leo-Guerra, a senior, writes.

title: Letter: My guardian angel
author: Dav King
abstract: I have muddied beliefs on an afterlife, but I know that somewhere out there Nugget is lying on a bench still getting pets from all kinds of people.

title: Letter: A very friendly dog
author: Daniel Hwang
abstract: Nugget served as a constant reminder that amid all the work you were caught up in, that home, comfort, and community were never too far away.

title: Letter: The spirit of our years at Duke
author: Charlie Zong
abstract: I thought that someday this summer, I would learn to shake her hand. I thought she might be there to see me graduate next spring. I thought we would always have more time.

title: Our culture is not your frat party
author: Cultural Organizations Coming Together
abstract: Selective social groups, unaffiliated or not, need more transparency in their systems to address racism, sexism, homophobia, xenophobia, ableism and sexual assault.

title: Editor's note: Regarding 2022 student Commencement speaker's time on The Chronicle
author: Milla Surjadi
abstract: A review of Parkash's published stories for The Chronicle found no evidence of plagiarism.

title: Letter to the Editor: Statement from 2022 student Commencement speaker
author: Priya Parkash
abstract: This statement was sent to The Chronicle on behalf of Parkash by Dave Quast, senior vice president of Red Banyan, a crisis public relations firm.

title: Letter: Thank you from Duke alumna
author: Amy Unell
abstract: Although I recently resigned from my role as Senior Director of Arts Engagement and Partnerships, I will always be a champion of the arts, DEMAN, StudioDuke and your friend.

title: The exclusivity of studying abroad at Duke
author: Kaylin Hernández
abstract: Duke University and the Global Education Office (GEO) should offer more diverse study abroad programs in Latin America and the Caribbean to better reflect the Latinx/Latine student body instead of overemphasizing Spain.

title: Duke learning is transactional; how we can do better
author: Grace Dessert
abstract: One of my favorite professors, Dr. Malone, once asked me, “Are you a stat, or a story?”

title: An open letter to Inside Joke
author: Anna Shenk-Evans
abstract: In that video, Inside Joke was not only equating Lia Thomas to a man, but also invalidating the existence and successes of all trans athletes.

title: Tsundoku, Gatsby, Marshmallows, Me
author: Jocelyn Chin
abstract: I wonder if I have problems prioritizing as I balance on scales, watch my weight drop, know it’s the cost of saving each HEERF fund, stimulus check, meal stipend, the cost of piling books on my windowsill instead.

title: Advice for the future CEB
author: Community Editorial Board
abstract: We are proud to announce that, this semester, our articles got "increasingly worse."

title: My two cents on a two minute decision
author: Linda Cao
abstract: We treat our doctors with pride and appreciation, but there’s a very heavy burden that follows the letters D and r.

title: Let’s liberate the liberal arts
author: Community Editorial Board
abstract: Fundamentally, the liberal arts must be, in a word, ‘liberal’—that is characterized by freedom of choice.

title: Feeling
author: Margot Armbruster
abstract: Just as I’m gentle on my knee so my knee supports my hip, I can maintain, as life continues, that all my seasons may count for me sometime.

title: Better late than never
author: Nithin Ragunathan
abstract: It’s natural to have regrets in life, but as The Chronicle chapter comes to a close, I only have one: Why didn’t I start sooner?

title: Why I watch sports
author: Evan Kolin
abstract: I’ve been a sports fan my entire life, but I’ll be the first to admit that I’ve never been as interested in the Xs and Os on the court or field as a lot of my peers.

title: Letting in the light
author: Matthew Griffin
abstract: As I look back on my time on this campus built to let in sunlight, I’m aware of what a privilege it’s been to spend my college career illuminating Duke and its community.

title: Like all good things
author: Leah Boyd
abstract: And the moment I stared out the window at the Chapel, my head swimming with memories instead of stress about the week ahead, I knew it was time for the end.

title: I just want to say thank you
author: Jake C. Piazza
abstract: If there’s one thing I’ve learned from The Chronicle, it’s that you never know when a lifelong memory is going to fall into your lap.

title: For a better Duke
author: Nadia Bey
abstract: Sure, we love Duke Athletics and we love when Duke moves up a place in some arbitrary ranking system and we love when our researchers make new discoveries, but holding the University accountable is a form of love, too.

title: Duke’s obligation to support the student-led solution to sexual assault
author: Community Editorial Board
abstract: Whether or not Duke has been looking for a solution to sexual assault on campus, SHAPE has done the heavy lifting for them.

title: Here goes a photographer's attempt to write
author: Simran Prakash
abstract: Over the years, I grew from someone who did not even know what to do with my new camera, only fascinated by the power of the iPhone 6 camera, into a girl whose entire life revolves around photography. I thank The Chronicle so deeply for that.

title: I love Duke
author: Ramona Naseri
abstract: It’s okay that I don’t know what’s happening next, because that means I can finally write this next chapter myself. And if there’s one thing writing for The Chronicle has taught me: it’s writing.

title: Thank you for the lessons
author: Maria Morrison
abstract: I’ve always felt that the office was a safe space, somewhere I could come to find those who would share in my joys or sorrows in equal measure. I feel genuinely loved, which is such a beautiful thing that is easy to take for granted.
